arm_group.description: Lung volume recruitment twice daily for 9 months

brief_summary.textblock:
Multiple sclerosis is a neurological disease that can affect lung function and cough
      efficacy. This pilot study will examine whether the lung volume recruitment technique can
      slow down the decline in lung function and cough.

clinical_study.brief_title: Lung Volume Recruitment for Lung Function and Cough Impairment in Multiple Sclerosis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  History of multiple sclerosis, diagnosed by a neurologist in accordance with the 2010
             McDonald criteria

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Concomitant parenchymal pulmonary disease or pleural disease

          -  Symptomatic cardiomyopathy

          -  Unable to perform pulmonary function testing or lung volume recruitment, due to
             comprehension or cooperation issues, physical inability such as bulbar or cerebellar
             dysfunction

          -  Contra-indication to pulmonary function testing or lung volume recruitment such as
             myocardial infarction, bleeding aortic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage within the
             previous month

          -  Known susceptibility to pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum

          -  Not competent to provide informed consent

intervention.description: Inflation of the lungs to their maximal insufflation capacity by the consecutive delivery, by a manual resuscitator in this study, of volumes of air that are held with a closed glottis

clinical_study.official_title: Lung Volume Recruitment for Lung Function and Cough Impairment in Multiple Sclerosis

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of decline of FVC (forced vital capacity)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of decline of peak cough flow
Change from baseline in FVC at 2, 4, 6 and 9 months
Change from baseline in peak cough flow at 2, 4, 6 and 9 months

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Prevention
